message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Shigella dysenteriae can invade intestinal M-cells and cause bloody diarrhea, which is consistent with this patient's symptoms. Escherichia coli can cause diarrhea, but does not typically invade M-cells. Salmonella enteritidis can cause diarrhea and bloody stools, but does not directly invade M-cells. Helicobacter pylori is a bacteria that is associated with stomach ulcers, but not diarrhea or M-cell invasion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, presence of red and white blood cells in the stool, and invasion of intestinal M-cells all suggest Shigella dysenteriae. Escherichia coli can cause similar symptoms but does not invade M-cells. Salmonella enteritidis is motile and can ferment lactose. Helicobacter pylori does not cause diarrhea or invade M-cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Shigella dysenteriae invades intestinal M-cells, leading to bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. E. coli and Salmonella can cause diarrhea, but they do not invade M-cells. H. pylori causes gastritis and peptic ulcers, not diarrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of abdominal pain and diarrhea and the presence of red and white blood cells in the stool suggest a bacterial infection. The key information is that the bacteria invade intestinal M-cells, which are cells that act as a portal for entry of bacteria and antigens into the lymphatic system. Shigella dysenteriae is known to invade M-cells and cause enteric fever. The other options do not specifically invade M-cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of abdominal pain and diarrhea, as well as the presence of red and white blood cells in the stool, suggest an infection. The bacteria that invade intestinal M-cells and cause this type of infection are Shigella dysenteriae. Options A, B, and D are known to cause different types of infections and do not invade M-cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and stool findings suggest an infection, and the fact that the bacteria invade intestinal M-cells points to Shigella dysenteriae. Escherichia coli and Salmonella enteritidis can also cause enteric infections, but they don't typically invade M-cells. Helicobacter pylori colonizes the stomach and is not associated with enteric infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bacteria that invade intestinal M-cells and cause bloody diarrhea are typical of Shigella dysenteriae. Choice A, Escherichia coli, can cause diarrhea but usually not bloody diarrhea. Choice B, Salmonella enteritidis, can cause bloody diarrhea but does not specifically target M-cells. Choice D, Helicobacter pylori, is associated with gastric ulcers and gastritis and does not cause diarrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of abdominal pain and diarrhea with the presence of red and white blood cells suggest an infection. Among the options, Shigella dysenteriae causes dysentery and invades the intestinal mucosa via M-cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Shigella dysenteriae is known to invade intestinal M-cells. The symptoms of abdominal pain and diarrhea also suggest Shigella dysenteriae as the cause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and stool culture results suggest that the patient has a bacterial infection of the intestines. Among the options, only Shigella dysenteriae invades intestinal M-cells and causes bloody diarrhea. Escherichia coli, Salmonella enteritidis, and Helicobacter pylori do not invade M-cells.
